title: Which political party will win the most seats in the next Northern Ireland Assembly election?
preds: SF is more organized and established.  Voters seem to year for stability right now and SF feels more like a familiar incumbent.
Polls are tightening which makes predicting transferred preference votes rather uncertain.
DUP steeply rising in opinion polls but still behind SF.

"Sinn Féin ‘striking balance between Irish unity and bread and butter issues’ as it launches Northern election manifesto" https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/sinn-fein-striking-balance-between-irish-unity-and-bread-and-butter-issues-as-it-launches-northern-election-manifesto-41586267.html  https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/apr/25/northern-ireland-what-could-historic-election-win-for-sinn-fein-mean https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/decade-of-opportunity-for-irish-unity-has-begun-says-sinn-f%C3%A9in-leader-1.4861708 https://www.reuters.com/world/sinn-fein-calls-dublin-plan-constitutional-change-2022-04-25/
Facist party will rise out of nowhere
Sinn Fein is currently trying to get all nationalist voters under their tent by stating that a reunification of the Irish nations was "closer than ever before".

Using a Bayesian approach, my probability after looking at the recent polls for Sinn Fein did not change, so I maintained a 60% probability of them winning. That coupled with my previous probability at 60% brought me to the new probability of 69% as outlined below. With the forces at play in the Northern Ireland Assembly Election, Sinn Fein is consistently keeping the edge in the polls with gives me confidence in their ability to succeed. However, divergent forces could change the stance of Sinn Fein quickly, which is why I do not give them a near certain probability of winning.  1. .60*.60	
2. .60*.60 + .40(1-.60)
3. .36/.36 +.16
4. .36/.52 = 0.6923
Upping Sinn Fein based on latest polling https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/poll-puts-sinn-fein-on-course-to-be-largest-stormont-party-41344344.html

It was difficult for me to take a look back at this and make changes. I was pretty comfortable with my prior percentages of 31%, 66%, and 3%. With that being said, I didn't shift my numbers a whole lot but did strengthen the probability in Sinn Fein's favor slightly due to the continued chaos in the Unionist Party. https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/feb/04/election-fears-form-backdrop-to-dups-crazy-drama-in-northern-ireland

Coming back to this forecast I applied the Bayesian approach by taking the probability of Sinn Fein winning in the next Northern Ireland winning in the next election, which without any knowledge (x) it was 50% or .50 then the conditional probability of an event happening, in this case Sinn Fein leading in the polls (y) at 75%. Then using the conditional probability of Y not happening (z) was 25%, I used the formula: (X)(Y)/(X)(Y) + (Z) = Probability of Sinn Fein Winning (.50)(.75)/(.50)(.75) + (.25) = .375/.625 = .60 Thus, my forecast dropped from 75% for Sinn Fein winning to 60% when utilizing a Bayesian approach.

No MP by MP polls available readily, but overall polls continue to trend to Sinn Fein https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/uknews/stormont-poll-puts-sinn-f-c3-a9in-on-course-to-be-largest-party-after-next-assembly-election/ar-AAT1TdD?ocid=BingNewsSearch&pfr=1

Although DUP has current majority in the Assembly, there seems to be a strong push in the Sinn Féin party following the Brexit fall out along with internal issues in the DUP, such as frequently changing leadership choices. Polls show Sinn Féin as the current leader with the preference for other parties growing.  https://elections-daily.com/2021/11/19/the-2022-northern-ireland-assembly-election-six-months-out/

Historically, the DUP has garnered support in Northern Ireland but over time Sinn Fein has captured more support. The left-leaning republican nationalist party has garnered heavy amounts of support in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland over the past year giving it a boost in the probability of earning the most seats in the Northern Ireland Assembly. With the fallout of Brexit, Northern Ireland residents may not fully embrace conservative policies and the pro-Brexit party of the DUP which would drive them to main contender of Sinn Fein.

Opinion polling in the NI is showing a clear consistent lead for the SF party in the past 6 months - plus the lead is consistent and increasing in some pollsters in the past month. If all things remain constant, SF should win a plurality of seats and then the process of government formation will be interesting to follow.
Brexit and the issue of customs in the Irish Sea is likely to push voters away from Unionist parties.
DUP and UUP seem to be competing for the same voters, so unless one of them clearly wins over the other and collects the vote, Sinn Fein will win

Based on what would happen if an election was held today, Sinn Fein would win a majority. The DUP are too strident in their criticism of the protocol which doesn't seem to be an issue for many beyond their base. With Sinn Fein on the rise in the Republic, a changing demographic and a public sick of the DUP, Sinn Fein is best placed to win the most seats.

If the election were held today, there is little doubt that Sinn Fein would win most seats, based on the opinion polls.  There may be some evidence of disaffected DUP voters coming home as the election nears.  But for now, I am going to assume that the opinion polls are predictive.  There remains a good chance that the unionist vote splits three ways and without electoral cooperation will result in Sinn Fein out-performing its first preference share in seats gained.
It will follow usual lines of voting but Sinn Fein has the edge this time
Due to Brexit and Sinn Fein performing well in the polling

The key constituency for this question is going to be Fermanagh and South Tyrone
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermanagh_and_South_Tyrone_(Assembly_constituency) which has seen a reduction by one seat after the 2017 election to five as of now. It is possibly a blueprint for an ongoing increasing polarization IN GENERAL  of NI voters between extreme unionism (represented by the UUP) and active national separatism (represented by Sinn Fein) on the other pole. ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election#Distribution_of_seats_by_constituency ) 
 However, Fermanagh and South Tyrone does have some particularities:
/Seats that were formerly occupied by SDLP have been won by Sinn Fein in the past (first in 1975, then again in 2011)
/Seats on the unionist side are heavily contested between UUP and DUP, one seat of the UUP turned DUP through the party defection of the MLA Arlene Isabel Foster in 2004 ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlene_Foster#Assembly_career ). She used to be a high-profile MLA ever since until the RHIgate ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_Heat_Incentive_scandal ) triggered by her seriously distorted NI politics for years, until the New Decade, New Approach (NDNA) agreement was found ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Decade,_New_Approach ). Despite the scandal, her seat remained with the DUP in the 2017 election and was gained by MLA Deborah Erskine.
/Amazingly, Foster survived the scandal politically thoughout the "Collapse of the Northern Ireland Executive" 2016 through 2020 and even Brexit ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlene_Foster#Northern_Ireland_political_deadlock,_2017%E2%80%932020 , https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Ireland_(Executive_Formation_etc)_Act_2019 )and even became First Minister in 2020 again. It remains to be seen how voters will judge Foster publicly  tying her political career to such unfortunate figures as Theresa May and Boris Johnson in the Brexit matters. /The "Irish Language Act" was a big political win for all nationalist parties involved when introduced through the NDNA agreement ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Language_Act ), it is likely to remind voters of the Unionists parties' weakness in their everyday life ahead of the next election and could enforce a realistic separatist movement.
/Moreover, Fermanagh and South Tyrone is, by its long border with the Republic of Ireland, likely one the constituencies most exposed to post-BREXIT border troubles on the Irish island, which may influence the sentiment towards the central UK government and the Unionist ideology significantly. /As a conclusion, the UUP is likely to lose their only remaining seat in Fermanagh and South Tyrone to the DUP, whereas the DUP, as a consequence of the Foster legacy, may lose the other seat to moderate nationalist voters.
In sum, and ceteris paribus, Sinn Fein may turn out strongest with at least 28 seats, while UUP is in further decay along with the DUP winning 28 seats or less.
/Considering MLAs not seeking re-election ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election#Members_not_seeking_re-election )
the most likely changes observed will happen in
Lagan Valley, where Ind. MLA Trevor Lunn's seat is for grabs likely to Sinn Fein and
South Down, where SDLP MLA Sinéad Bradley's seat could also be contested by either Sinn Fein or UUP.
Other vacant seats without incumbent are likely to remain with the respective party's new contestant. Unless party arithmetics are newly riffled by the formation of formal party alliances/voting blocks, Sinn Féin is likely to be the party winning most seats in May 2022.
https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/politics/dup-battling-back-but-sinn-feins-michelle-oneill-still-on-course-for-first-minister-41047391.html

Fixed calculation. I should make a spreadsheet or something. See edit in previous comment [1], I previously misread the Wiki page as DUP winning 6 of 6 previous elections when they only won 5 of 6. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1366096

Assume all have even chances: 1:1:1. Since 1998 (Good Friday agreement), DUP have won all but one NI election (5 of 6 elections): 6:1:2 [1]. In the last 2 elections DUP held the lead in opinion polling [2, 3] and won both. Currently, SF holds the lead in opinion polling [4]. If this doubles or even triples SF's chances, we're still at 5:3:2 in the strongest case; minimum 50% for DUP. I don't think there's a really good reason to triple SF's chances based on polling -- I've simply not got the data and 3x is huge. I'll settle for 2x. Final odds: 5:2:2 = 55% DUP, 22% SF, 22% other. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Northern_Ireland#Elections_to_the_Northern_Ireland_Assembly
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election#Graphical_summary
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election#Graphical_summary
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election#Opinion_polls EDIT: Fixed calculation :-|
Although DUP has been strong, SF has made steady gains and appears to be in a strong position. Ulster Unionists, Social Democrats and Alliance will take almost 30% of the seats
Unionist Parties in Belfast and England are making a mess of it.

Both the main parties are likely to get squeezed, but the DUP look like getting squeezed the most. Alliance/SDLP/Green should eat into the SF vote a bit. But I expect TUV to significantly increase their vote from 2017 - maybe as high as 10% - which will create major problems for the DUP.

DUPs handling of the Brexit fallout is definitely a major factor here - most recent pole by Belfast Telegrah has Sinn Fein with a small lead (~2% - although unsure how biased the population on this one is). https://m.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/dup-lag-behind-sinn-fein-as-nis-biggest-party-in-latest-poll-41021442.html
Seeing a larger spread (4-6%) on most other polls: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election  Given Sinn Féin’s current push for a border referendum this may cause a backlash at some point but definitely the key issue will be how each party handles post Brexit protocol on NI. Any proposal of a long term border in the Irish Sea will cause a major backlash from Unionists.

The 6th Northern Ireland Assembly voted by the March 2017 election was the most even in representation between DUP and Sinn Fein since the Good Friday Agreement implemented the legislative body in 1998.  18 districts each post 5 MPs to the Assembly. Sinn Fein MP gains appear to have come from increased apportionment in districts that were already strongly supportive of Sinn Fein - Belfast West, South Down, Newry & Armagh, Fermanagh & S. Tyrone, West Tyrone, Mid Ulster. 
It appears only 4 other districts are competitive for a potential MP gain for Sinn Fein - East Londonderry, Upper Bann, Belfast South, Belfast North. 
DUP 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election Sinn Fein has demonstrated its political viability by winning the largest number of votes in Republic of Ireland elections held in 2020. While Sinn Fein is in opposition due to coalition of Fianna Fail, Fine Gael, and the Green Party, it appears to remain a strong political movement with little negative press, scandal, or problems. An additional factor that will impact this election will be how Protocol 16 of Brexit is handled by the UK government. DUP and other unionists have seen their position and preference consistently undermined by UK parliament as the focus has been on securing territorial and customs protections for UK. This has caused a 'soft' customs and border arrangement to be implemented across the Irish Sea to prevent reinstatement of a hard border between Northern Ireland and Republic of Ireland. To date Brexit implementation has come at the cost of Northern Ireland unionist positions and it doesn't appear there is political will or power to change the balance. This should further undermine DUP. Base rate would say slight edge to Sinn Fein based on trend, district analysis, and larger Republic of Ireland success for Sinn Fein.  I will attribute 2% noise to potential resurgence of UUP if DUP implodes in response to Brexit or potential scandal.  SDLP might have also have a resurgence however that seems very unlikely due to trend of SDLP in Republic of Ireland.

The DUP has won 5/6 elections since 1998.  However, the DUP has been steadily losing support since late 2019.  Brexit and the Northern Ireland protocol have significantly affected Northern Ireland.  This will be the first election after the protocol takes effect.  Sinn Fein's popularity has remained stable, while Unionist voters seem to be favoring other Unionist parties.  Other small parties have not won elections since 1998.
